greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If A139251 is written as a triangle with rows of lengths 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ..., the n-th row begins with 2^n followed by the first 2^n-1 terms of the present sequence.
comment: Limiting behavior of the rows of the triangle in A139251 when the first column of that triangle is omitted.
First differences of A159795. - _Omar E. Pol_, Jul 24 2009

It appears that a(n) is also the number of new grid points that are covered at n-th stage of A139250 version "Tree", assuming the toothpicks have length 4, 3, and 2 (see also A159795 and A153006). - _Omar E. Pol_, Oct 25 2011
link: David Applegate, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..2047

David Applegate, Omar E. Pol and N. J. A. Sloane, The Toothpick Sequence and Other Sequences from Cellular Automata, Congressus Numerantium, Vol. 206 (2010), 157-191. [There is a typo in Theorem 6: (13) should read u(n) = 4.3^(wt(n-1)-1) for n >= 2.]
N. J. A. Sloane, Catalog of Toothpick and Cellular Automata Sequences in the OEIS
Index entries for sequences related to toothpick sequences
formula: Letting n = 2^i + j for 0 <= j < 2^i, we have the recurrence (see A139251 for proof):
It appears that a(n) = A151548(n-1) + A151548(n). - _Omar E. Pol_, Feb 19 2015
example: Further comments: A139251 as a triangle is:
Note that this can also be written as a triangle:
The first column is (n+1)2^n (where n is the row number),
and the rest exhibits the same constant column behavior,
Once again this can be written as a triangle:
and this behavior continues ad infinitum.
xref: Equals 2*A151688 and 4*A152980. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jul 16 2009
